channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Columbia students barricade themselves in campus building; China's EV vehicles
item.description: Pro-Palestinian student protesters have occupied a campus building. Electric vehicles are the newest front of competition between the U.S. and China.
item.content:encoded:
Pro-Palestinian student protesters have occupied a campus building. Electric vehicles are the newest front of competition between the U.S. and China.

(Image credit: Alex Kent)
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Nuyen

item.title: Scientists restore brain cells impaired by a rare genetic disorder
item.description: A therapy that restores brain cells impaired by a rare genetic disorder may offer a strategy for treating conditions like autism, epilepsy, and schizophrenia.
item.content:encoded: A therapy that restores brain cells impaired by a rare genetic disorder may offer a strategy for treating conditions like autism, epilepsy, and schizophrenia.
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: As pro-Palestinian protests spread, more university leaders weigh police involvement
item.description: As college administrators face growing unrest on campuses, a growing number are grappling with whether to bring in law enforcement to quell the demonstrations.
item.content:encoded: As college administrators face growing unrest on campuses, a growing number are grappling with whether to bring in law enforcement to quell the demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Meg Anderson

item.title: AI is contentious among authors. So why are some feeding it their own writing?
item.description: Many authors are concerned about the use of their copyrighted material in generative AI models. At the same time, some are actively experimenting with the technology.
item.content:encoded: Many authors are concerned about the use of their copyrighted material in generative AI models. At the same time, some are actively experimenting with the technology.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Veltman

item.title: A U.S. diplomat tells NPR why she resigned in protest over the policy in Gaza
item.description: As protests against the U.S. policy in Gaza unfold on college campuses across the country, the State Department is facing its own protests too.
item.content:encoded: As protests against the U.S. policy in Gaza unfold on college campuses across the country, the State Department is facing its own protests too.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly

item.title: Abortion rights on the ballot may not be bad news for Republicans everywhere
item.description: More states than ever are gearing up to vote on abortion rights this fall, including Republican-led Missouri. There, voters could show the issue isn't a down-ballot Democratic dream everywhere.
item.content:encoded: More states than ever are gearing up to vote on abortion rights this fall, including Republican-led Missouri. There, voters could show the issue isn't a down-ballot Democratic dream everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Jason Rosenbaum

item.title: Victims of harassment by federal judges often find the judiciary is above the law
item.description: Federal judges have enormous power over their courtrooms and their chambers, which can leave employees vulnerable to abuse, with few ways to report their concerns anonymously.
item.content:encoded: Federal judges have enormous power over their courtrooms and their chambers, which can leave employees vulnerable to abuse, with few ways to report their concerns anonymously.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: A simple smile saved this man's life
item.description: Ken Wilcox's life felt hopeless, like there was nowhere left to turn. Then a simple act from a stranger on the street changed his perspective and his life.
item.content:encoded: Ken Wilcox's life felt hopeless, like there was nowhere left to turn. Then a simple act from a stranger on the street changed his perspective and his life.
item.dc:creator: Autumn Barnes

item.title: Sign here? Financial agreements may leave doctors in the driver's seat
item.description: Agreeing to an out-of-network doctor's financial policy, which protects their ability to get paid and may be littered with confusing jargon, can create a binding contract that leaves a patient owing.
item.content:encoded:
Agreeing to an out-of-network doctor's financial policy, which protects their ability to get paid and may be littered with confusing jargon, can create a binding contract that leaves a patient owing.

(Image credit: Bridget Bennett for KFF Health News)
item.dc:creator: Katheryn Houghton

item.title: Protesters at Columbia University have begun occupying a campus building
item.description: Students began occupying Hamilton Hall early Tuesday morning. The university's public safety department urged people to avoid coming to the Morningside campus Tuesday if they could.
item.content:encoded:
Students began occupying Hamilton Hall early Tuesday morning. The university's public safety department urged people to avoid coming to the Morningside campus Tuesday if they could.

(Image credit: Alex Kent)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie
